column2: CHAPTER XI.
column3: CHAPTER eleven.

column2: THE STORY GIRL DOES PENANCE
column3: THE STORY GIRL DOES PENANCE

column2: Ten days later, Aunt Olivia and Uncle Roger went to town one evening, to remain over night, and the next day.
column3: Ten days later, Aunt Olivia and Uncle Roger went to town one evening, to remain over night, and the next day.

column2: Peter and the Story Girl were to stay at Uncle Alec's during their absence.
column3: peter and the Story Girl were to stay at Uncle Alec's during their absence.

column2: We were in the orchard at sunset, listening to the story of King Cophetua and the beggar maid--all of us, except Peter, who was hoeing turnips, and Felicity, who had gone down the hill on an errand to Mrs. Ray.
column3: We were in the orchard at sunset, listening to the story of King Cophetua and the beggar maid-all of us, except peter, who was hoeing turnips, and Felicity, who had gone down the hill on an errand to mrs Ray.

column2: The Story Girl impersonated the beggar maid so vividly, and with such an illusion of beauty, that we did not wonder in the least at the king's love for her.
column3: The Story Girl impersonated the beggar maid so vividly, and with such an illusion of beauty, that we did not wonder in the least at the king's love for her.

column2: I had read the story before, and it had been my opinion that it was "rot." No king, I felt certain, would ever marry a beggar maid when he had princesses galore from whom to choose.
column3: I had read the story before, and it had been my opinion that it was "rot." No king, I felt certain, would ever marry a beggar maid when he had princesses galore from whom to choose.

column2: But now I understood it all.
column3: But now I understood it all.

column2: When Felicity returned we concluded from her expression that she had news.
column3: When Felicity returned we concluded from her expression that she had news.

column2: And she had.

column2: Sara is real sick, she said, with regret, and something that was not regret mingled in her voice.
column3: Sara is real sick, she said, with regret, and something that was not regret mingled in her voice.

column2: She has a cold and sore throat, and she is feverish.	She has a cold and sore throat, and she is feverish.

column2: AND SHE IS AFRAID IT'S THE MEASLES."

column3: Where else could she have caught them? said Felicity mercilessly.

column2: I'm going to do penance all day for coaxing Sara to disobey her mother, she announced with chastened triumph.

column3: And if any of you think of anything I don't, just mention it to me.
